It looks like you're experiencing a compatibility issue with the KSP (Kotlin Symbol Processing) plugin. This typically happens when there's a version mismatch between KSP and Kotlin versions, or when the versions are incompatible with your Gradle version.

Here's how to fix it:

1. Make sure your `libs.versions.toml` has compatible KSP and Kotlin versions
2. Update your Gradle configuration

## Solution

```gradle.kts:app/build.gradle.kts
// ... existing code ...

plugins {
 alias(libs.plugins.android.application)
 alias(libs.plugins.kotlin.android)
 alias(libs.plugins.kotlin.compose)
 alias(libs.plugins.ksp)
 alias(libs.plugins.hilt)
}

// ... existing code ...
```

## Steps to resolve:

1. Check your `libs.versions.toml` file (in the `gradle` folder) and make sure KSP version is compatible with your Kotlin version
2. Try these troubleshooting steps:

 - Run "File > Invalidate Caches and Restart"
 - Delete the `.gradle` folder in your project and sync again
 - Run "File > Sync Project with Gradle Files"
 - Update your Gradle version in `gradle/wrapper/gradle-wrapper.properties`
 - Make sure your KSP version matches your Kotlin version (generally, they should have matching version numbers)

## Example compatible versions (update your libs.versions.toml):

```toml
[versions]
ksp = "1.9.22-1.0.17" # Should match your Kotlin version with KSP suffix
kotlin = "1.9.22" # Make sure these match

[plugins]
ksp = { id = "com.google.devtools.ksp", version.ref = "ksp" }
kotlin-android = { id = "org.jetbrains.kotlin.android", version.ref = "kotlin" }
```
